maml:description.maml:para: Connect to an OPNsense server using the REST api
The Connect-OPNsense cmdlet will try to connect to an OPNsense server REST api. You need to specify the Key and Secret obtained when enabling the REST api.

Optionally specify a username and password for the WebUI in order to use the Backup-OPNsenseConfig, Restore-OPNsenseConfig and Reset-OPNsenseConfig cmdlets. These actions do not have a REST api equivalent yet and need the webcredentials to perform these commands on the server.
If the server is using a self-signed certificate and your computer fails to validate it, you can temporarily disable the Certificate Validation using the -SkipCertificateCheck switch.
Full URI of the OPNsense REST api including the protocol and hostname. Optionally specify the port of the webservice.

Credentials for the REST api, this is the key and secret pair received when enabling the api for an OPNsense user. If you only specify a string, it will be interpreted as the key and you will be prompted to enter the secret.

Optional credentials for the web interface. These credentials are only used for legacy commands that do not have a REST api equivalent yet. If you only specify a string, it will be interpreted as the username and you will be prompted to enter the password.
Bypass the server certificate validation, use this for accepting self-signed server certificates.
Full URI of the OPNsense REST api including the protocol and hostname. Optionally specify the port of the webservice.
The REST api key generated by OPNsense.

Optional credentials for the web interface. These credentials are only used for legacy commands that do not have a REST api equivalent yet. If you only specify a string, it will be interpreted as the username and you will be prompted to enter the password.
Bypass the server certificate validation, use this for accepting self-signed server certificates.
Full URI of the OPNsense REST api including the protocol and hostname. Optionally specify the port of the webservice.
The REST api key generated by OPNsense.

Credentials for the REST api, this is the key and secret pair received when enabling the api for an OPNsense user. If you only specify a string, it will be interpreted as the key and you will be prompted to enter the secret.

Optional credentials for the web interface. These credentials are only used for legacy commands that do not have a REST api equivalent yet. If you only specify a string, it will be interpreted as the username and you will be prompted to enter the password.
Bypass the server certificate validation, use this for accepting self-signed server certificates.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Basic example --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
$webCred = Get-Credential -Username 'root' -Message 'Enter the password for the WebUI:'
$secureSecret = ConvertTo-SecureString -String "api_secret" -AsPlainText -Force $apiCred = New-Object -TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -ArgumentList ("api_key", $secureSecret)
Connect-OPNsense -Url 'https://opnsense.localdomain:8080' -Credential $apiCred -WebCredential $webCred

dev:remarks.maml:para: Display a popup requesting for the WebUI credentials with default username of root. Then build the credentials for the REST api from "api_key" and "api_secret" strings. Finally call the Connect-OPNsense cmdlet with the hostname, api credentials and web credentials.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example prompting for the secret and password --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Disable a CronJob in OPNsense
Disable a CronJob in OPNsense using its UUID. The UUID can be retrieved with Get-OPNsenseCronJob.
UUID of the CronJob to disable
UUID of the CronJob to disable
Disconnect from an OPNsense server REST api
The Disconnect-OPNsense cmdlet will remove any reference to the connected OPNsense server. You will have to use the Connect-OPNsense cmdlet again to reconnect.
Enable a CronJob in OPNsense
Enable a CronJob in OPNsense using its UUID. The UUID can be retrieved with Get-OPNsenseCronJob.
UUID of the CronJob to enable
UUID of the CronJob to enable
Return the basic status information about the OPNsense server

Use this command to list basic status information of the OPNsense server, like its Product Version and Product Name. The command will first contact the mirror repository and check if any updates are available.

Use the Get-OPNsense cmdlet to retrieve the number of updates pending and to check whether a reboot will be needed. If updates are available, use the Update-OPNsense cmdlet to install them and reboot the server when required.
List the OPNsense package mirrors
List the OPNsense package mirrors
Retrieve CaptivePortal zones, templates or providers from OPNsense.

Use the Get-OPNsenseCaptivePortal cmdlet to retrieve zones, templates or providers from OPNsense. Specify either -Zone, -Template or -Provider to get a list of the objects. Optionally pass a UUID parameter the get the details of a specific zone or template.
Retrieve one or more CronJobs from OPNsense
If you do not specify an UUID the Get-OPNsenseCronJob cmdlet retrieves a list of all the CronJobs from OPNsense.
By passing a UUID to Get-OPNsenseCronJob the cmdlet will only retrieve the details of the specified CronJob.
UUID of the CronJob to retrieve
UUID of the CronJob to retrieve
Get a list of the packages in OPNsense
Retrieve a list of the packages in OPNsense.
Retrieve information about one or more packages in OPNsense.
The name(s) of the packages to display.
Only list the packages that are installed on the OPNsense server. To return the packages that are not installed, specify -Installed:$false
Only list the packages that have been locked. To return the packages that are unlocked, specify -Locked:$false
The name(s) of the packages to display.
Only list the packages that are installed on the OPNsense server. To return the packages that are not installed, specify -Installed:$false
Only list the packages that have been locked. To return the packages that are unlocked, specify -Locked:$false

Run pkg audit -F on the server
FreeBSD registers vulnerabilities for its packages run this cmdlet to create visibility and awareness.
Output the raw text returned from OPNsense as opposed to formated data.
Output the raw text returned from OPNsense as opposed to formated data.

maml:description.maml:para: Execute an OPNsense command against the REST api of a connected server
The Invoke-OPNsenseCommand cmdlet will execute a command againt the OPNsense server REST api. This can be a simple query. You can also POST objects using a simple Form or complex Json structure.
Use the Connect-OPNsense cmdlet first to establisch a connection. Subsequent calls will not need credentials until you disconnect using Disconnect-OPNsense cmdlet.
If you specify an AddProperty HashTable, the Objects returned will each include the properties specified.
API module
API controller
API command
Form object to POST
Add extra property or properties to the return object
API module
API controller
API command
Json object to POST
Add extra property or properties to the return object
API module
API controller
API command
Add extra property or properties to the return object
API module
API controller
API command
Json object to POST
Form object to POST
Add extra property or properties to the return object

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Post JSON object --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-OPNsenseCommand ids settings test -Json @{ key1 = value1; key2 = value2 }

maml:description.maml:para: Lock a Package in OPNsense

The Lock-OPNsensePackage cmdlet locks the version of a package. It prevents the package from being updated by subsequent OPNsense updates. Use the to prevent unintended upgrades or downgrade to the package.
The name of the package to be locked
The name of the package to be locked
Remove a Package in OPNsense
Uninstalls a Package from the OPNsense server.
The name of the package to be removed
The name of the package to be removed
Reboot the OPNsense server
The Restart-OPNsense cmdlet will reboot the OPNsense server. Use this command with care, as this will make your appliance inaccessible while it restarts.

In order to prevent accidental reboots, the command will request user confirmation before executing the command on the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to reboot the server without user intervention.
Ask user confirmation before restarting the OPN server.
Ask user confirmation before restarting the OPN server.
Shutdown the OPNsense server

The Stop-OPNsense cmdlet will shutdown the OPNsense server. Use this command with extreme care, as this will make your appliance inaccessible. Make sure you have a means to power the server on before executing this cmdlet!

In order to prevent accidental shutdown, the command will request user confirmation before executing the command on the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to power down the server without user intervention.
Ask user confirmation before powering down the OPN server.
Ask user confirmation before powering down the OPN server.
Unlock a Package in OPNsense

The Unlock-OPNsensePackage cmdlet unlocks the version of a package. It allows the package to be updated by subsequent OPNsense updates. Use the to allow updating the package to the latest version using the Update-OPNsense cmdlet.
The name of the package to be unlocked
The name of the package to be unlocked
Update the OPNsense server base OS and packages

The Update-OPNsense cmdlet will run the update tool and install the pending updates on the OPSsense server. Use the Get-OPNsense cmdlet to retrieve the number of updates pending and to check whether a reboot will be required.

Because the server will reboot automatically when required, user confirmation is requested before updating the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to reboot the server without user intervention.
Ask user confirmation before updating the OPN server.
Ask user confirmation before updating the OPN server.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieve system health data from OPNsense

Use the Get-OPNsenseSystemHealth cmdlet to retrieve statistics about the OPNsense system health. There first switch determines the type of data returned and can be one of { Packets | System | Traffic } For Packet and Traffic statistics you need to specify the interface for which to return the data. For System statistics you need to specify the resource for which to return the data.

Use the Get-OPNsenseInterface cmdlet to retrieve a list of the available interfaces you can query. Use the Get-OPNsenseSystemResource cmdlet to retrieve a list of the available resources you can query.
The other parameters are optial and common to all commands. They specify the start and end date and resolution and zoomlevel of the data.
By default all data is shown as positive numbers. Use the Inverse switch to present outgoing interface packets or traffic values as negative numbers.
Return packet statistics
The interface for which to return packet or trafic information
Not implemented
Not implemented
Present outgoing interface packets or traffic values as negative numbers
Return traffic statistics
The interface for which to return packet or trafic information
Not implemented
Not implemented
Present outgoing interface packets or traffic values as negative numbers
Return system statistics
The resource for which to return system information
Not implemented
Not implemented
Present outgoing interface packets or traffic values as negative numbers
Return packet statistics
The interface for which to return packet or trafic information
Not implemented
Not implemented
Present outgoing interface packets or traffic values as negative numbers
Return traffic statistics
Return system statistics
The resource for which to return system information
Return the OPNsense interfaces
Return the OPNsense interfaces that can be used in the Get-OPNsenseSystemHealth cmdlet.
Return the OPNsense resources
Return the OPNsense resources that can be used in the Get-OPNsenseSystemHealth cmdlet.
List the ARP table from OPNsense
List the ARP table from OPNsense

maml:description.maml:para: Get the status of OPNsense services
Retrieve a status list of the OPNsense services.
Retrieve information about one or more services in OPNsense.
Name of the service
Name of the service
Restart an OPNsense service
Restarts an OPNsense service.
Name of the service
Name of the service
Start an OPNsense service
Starts an OPNsense service.
Name of the service
Name of the service
Stop an OPNsense service
Stops an OPNsense service
Name of the service
Name of the service
Reconfigure an OPNsense service
Reloads the configuration of an OPNsense service without restarting the service process.
Name of the service
Name of the service
Flush the OPNsense arp table on the server

Use the Clear-OPNsenseARP cmdlet to flush the contents of the arp table on the server. This can be useful when entries in the arp table are incorrect or you want to make sure the mac addresses are learned again.

In order to prevent an unintended flush of the arp table, the cmdlet will request user confirmation before executing the command on the OPNsense server. You must specify the -Confirm parameter if you want to flush the arp table without user intervention.
Configures the OPNsense firmware settings.
Use the Set-OPNsense cmdlet to configure the settings op the OPNsense firmware. These settings include the firmware mirror, flavour and subscription.
Use the Get-OPNsense -FirmwareOptions command to retrieve the options. Use the Get-OPNsense -Mirror command to retrieve the available mirrors.
The URi of the firmware mirror
The firmware flavour to use openssl, libressl, <blank> or a custom string.
The subscription location to use on the specified mirror. The location is appended to the mirror URI.
The URi of the firmware mirror
The firmware flavour to use openssl, libressl, <blank> or a custom string.
The subscription location to use on the specified mirror. The location is appended to the mirror URI.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Select the HiHo (Zurich, CH) mirror with the libressl flavour and without a subscription.

maml:description.maml:para: Backup the OPNsense config.xml file
Returns the contents of the config.xml file from the OPNsense server. This file contains all the configuration details and can be used to backup your OPNsense configuration.
Use the Restore-OPNsenseConfig cmdlet to restore the config.xml file to a previous version.
Include Round Robin Database data in the XML output.
Encrypt the result with a choosen password.
Include Round Robin Database data in the XML output.
Encrypt the result with a choosen password.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command uses the webinterface. It needs the webcredentials to be specified using Connect-OPNsense -WebCredential first.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the ClamAV configuration from the OPNsense server

The Get-OPNsenseClamAV cmdlet returns the current configuration of the Clam Anti-Virus service on the OPNsense server. Use the optional -Version switch to retieve the version details of ClamAV and the virus definition files installed.
The os-clamav package needs to be installed. Use Install-OPNsensePackage to install the os-clamav package if needed.
Get the version of ClamAV and its virus definitions.
Get the version of ClamAV and its virus definitions.
Invokes a command for a specific service
Trigger a command from a service depending an the parameters passed.
Triggers the FreshClam service to update the ClamAV definitions.
Triggers the FreshClam service to update the ClamAV definitions.
Resetthe OPNsense server to factory defaults

WARNING: This cmdlet destroys the configuration on the OPNsense server. Use the Reset-OPNsenseConfig cmdlet with extreme caution. In order to prevent accidentally wiping your OPNsense server, this cmdlet will request confirmation before executing the reset to factory defaults on the server.
You need to pass all the required parameters for the cmdlet to have effect. This is to prevent from unknowingly destroying your server.
Needs to be passed for the cmdlet to have effect.
Confirm the hostname of the server you want to reset.
Test the command without actually performing the reset.
Ask user confirmation before reseting the OPNsense server to factory defaults.
Needs to be passed for the cmdlet to have effect.
Confirm the hostname of the server you want to reset.
Test the command without actually performing the reset.
Ask user confirmation before reseting the OPNsense server to factory defaults.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command uses the webinterface. It needs the webcredentials to be specified using Connect-OPNsense -WebCredential first.

Reset-OPNsenseConfig : 'SomeOtherServer' doesn't match the hostname of the server. You need to specify 'OPNsense.localdomain' to reset the configuration. maml:description.maml:para: Restore the OPNsense config.xml file

Upload the contents of config.xml to the OPNsense server. This cmdlet will overwrite the current configuration with the new configuration. You can specify either a path to a file or pass the contents of the XML directly. WARNING: The server will reboot automatically after restoring the configuration.
If required, use the Backup-OPNsenseConfig cmdlet first to save a local copy of the config.xml file before overwriting the current configuration.
The XML string to restore to the config.xml file on the server.
The password to decrypt the config.xml file in case it is encrypted.
Local path of the config.xml file to restore back to the server.
The password to decrypt the config.xml file in case it is encrypted.
The XML string to restore to the config.xml file on the server.
The password to decrypt the config.xml file in case it is encrypted.
Local path of the config.xml file to restore back to the server.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command uses the webinterface. It needs the webcredentials to be specified using Connect-OPNsense -WebCredential first.

Enables one or more OPNsense objects based on their UUID within the REST api. You can pass multiple UUIDs, but they must all belong to the same object type. You cannot mix UUIDs of different object types. Use Get-OPNsense to retieve the UUID of an object.
